segments.text: Today is Friday the 29th of January, this is a test.

Last time we were discussing the job that you had as Deputy Chief and then Chief of the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project and you were there from 1951 until 1957 and we were talking about some of the personalities, we were talking about
LeMay is where we ended up.
I'd like to talk right now about another personality that you must have known, Teller, Edward Teller, the so-called father of the H-bomb.
What type of relationship did you have with him?
A rather lengthy one and varied.
I have a Christmas card over there that I got from Dr. and Mrs. Teller this Christmas.
Dr. Teller, of course, was in the original group of scientists working on the A-bomb and was at Los Alamos.
And after the war was over and we began—then the Atomic Energy Commission formed, and we established another laboratory at Livermore, California, and he was made director of that laboratory.
And as such, worked with the commission on

all of the things related to operating a laboratory, what research program they would have, what funds they would have, what budget, what kind of hiring policies, and all of the things that are involved in running an entity of that sort.
And as a member of the Military Liaison Committee staff,
And later in the Enforcer Special Weapons Project, we were interested in and had inputs to essentially all of the projects that either of the laboratories was doing.
And so we had a continuous liaison with an officer there on the laboratory.
us, and very frequent meetings and discussions with the personnel of the laboratory, including Teller.
And so we probably sat down together once every two weeks to once every month
for the full time that I was in the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project.
I worked with them on the research program for weapons, the testing program, the weapons effects program, their research programs into other areas of military interest, testing problems.
Well, just about anything you can think of in connection with the nuclear weapons field, nuclear weapons and nuclear propulsion field.
And during this period of time, work also began, research work on the fusion field for power.
And of course, it continued in the weapons field.

And this relationship of course was closer still when I took his weapons to the Pacific to test them and his laboratory personnel and even more so when I came back from that and took over as general manager of AEC and
was therefore headed the entity to which he submitted all his plans and programs and budget requirements and other things.
So worked very closely with him there until I left there at the end of six years to go to the Jet Propulsion Lab.
And while I saw him several times after that, including a couple of times here at Texas A&M,
I've not been working with him because he's still in that business and I'm in some other business.
What was your opinion of him?
I said the same thing, I guess, about a good many people.
He was a wonderful, wonderful man, wonderful person.
I have very deepest respect for him.
and for his capabilities, as well as his qualities as a human being and as a man.
He's considerate, compassionate.
He believes strongly, and he makes his case strongly, and sticks to it, and usually wins.
One of the major issues was the disagreement between Oppenheimer and Teller on the development of the H-bomb.
Would you like to comment on that?
To the extent to recognize that one was on one side of the fence and one on the other,
arguments would be what one, bring out the points that one would expect.
Needless to say, I was in full agreement with Teller and not in agreement with Oppenheimer, so it wasn't hard to determine where my sympathies were.
Some people have charged, and it might be an unfair charge, that Teller was influential in congressional hearings.
in persuading the government to take Oppenheimer's security clearance away?
I have no personal knowledge of this, but I do not believe it's so.
I can't speak from personal knowledge, but I do not believe it's true.
What impact did the development of the H-bomb
have on the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project?
Well, it broadened our approach.
I mean, all of the functions that we had to perform, we had to now expand by orders of magnitude in terms of the increased power that we would expect from this development.
One of the roughest things that happened to us was propelling us immediately into the, beyond the technology available in cryogenics.
Because in the early approach to the H-bomb,
everything had to be done close to absolute zero temperature.
And this is a very costly and extremely difficult problem.
And we, as other development agencies, were involved heavily.
as we went down the road, we found a way to get around this and could abandon that approach.
I have a notion that the United States learned more about the physics and chemistry of low temperatures in a couple of years than they probably learned in all the rest of history.
Besides the development of the H-bomb, there were other new weapons that were developed in the 1950s.
Would you comment on those special projects that you people worked on?
Well, one has to be very careful here of security.
I've been out of the process now for a number of years.
I don't know all of the things that have been classified or declassified.
But one of our primary objectives was to get the explosive power up and the weight down such that they could be handled in our intercontinental ballistic missiles and other applications.
Because the penalty and delivery systems that one pays for heavy weight is very great indeed.
So a pound off of the portion to be delivered sometimes is 100 pounds or more off of the total weight of what one has to launch or move.
And so that was one of the big objectives.

The other, of course, is getting any of the weapons so that they have a long life in storage or in inactive status, because you certainly hope that's the way they're going to stay, and to be absolutely
sure on all aspects of safety.
And so, very much of the energy went into this area.
The other major area of effort was that of determining weapons of fact, of
various kinds and magnitudes of detonations.
And our agency was the one charged fully with that responsibility.
So much of our energy was there.
And of course, this took the cooperation of the laboratories, the development people, the researchers.
everyone in the business in order to pin down the effects.
So, we could summarize by saying that your mission then was dealt with reducing weight, longevity, safety, and the effects.
And deliverability, yeah.
And the deliverability.
Okay.

now concerning the effects and this is we were talking before about this and this is very important it's been in the news recently uh you've been at uh as far as you know more atomic blasts than any other human at one time okay i'm not necessarily true now yes and uh i'd like to
I'd like you to tell me about some of the early testing and some of the findings.
You know, things of course that are not classified, but some of the findings.
What were you looking for, and what did you find, and did you expect to find the things that you were looking for?
In the effects area, and I think you were talking effects rather than development.
In the effects area,
I don't think we really found any surprises.
If we did, they were surprises on the safe side rather than on the horror side.
If you remember earlier all of the talk of
sterility resulting from exposure of just almost any amount.
And everyone was scared.

We found, I think, as we should have expected to find, that yes, it can create sterility if the dose is high enough and sustained long enough, the same as can x-ray or exposures to a bit many other things.
The argument is still, of course, going on heavily as to the results of the effects of exposure to low-level radiation over long periods of time, particularly.
And I don't think that anyone's going to know all the answers to that for a good many years yet.
from the work that we did, we were convinced that this effect was very minimal, and in some cases even beneficial.
And if the exposure was not sufficiently rapid that your body couldn't take care of it, that it did in fact get busy to repair much of the
uh, damage that is done by the radiation.

And so we think that the fear of it is a very much more dangerous effect than the effect of the radiation itself, except in direct exposure to, uh, either to explosions, I mean direct exposure, direct exposure to explosion,
or direct exposure to hard radiation from reactors or power-producing reactions.
With respect to the other effects, particularly blast, as soon as one knows the characteristic of the blast wave,
computation can then come very close to determining the effect of any particular blast on any particular plate or point.
So there's nothing really mysterious about that one.
The explosion has a
blast wave and blast effects that are quite different from dynamite or TNT or some other explosive, but they are alike within themselves.
I mean, a nuclear detonation is a nuclear detonation, and its blast wave has certain characteristics, and it'll be the same yesterday as tomorrow.
So that one, though taking a very great deal of work to pin down, is not subject to particular controversy or further difficulty.
And so far as the danger from radiation is concerned, it is very much overdone, except what might result
from direct exposure to a nuclear detonation, such as you would have in war, such as you had at Hiroshima or Nagasaki.
That one, in my view, is blown out of proportion, too, because the people who were directly exposed either were killed, or if they survived, the effects were certainly observable.
We have been following every family that was over there that were within certain ranges of the explosion, or even said they were in there.
And I think we haven't learned a great deal about anything, in fact, from that.
Well, you know, when you open up a newspaper or a magazine, often you see articles dealing with, well, the 60 Minutes.
You probably saw 60 Minutes a couple of years ago.
I think Mike Wallace had the program in which he interviewed some veterans who had been at some of the 1950 blasts out in
Oh Tim, Nevada, and you know, it was played up like the American government were using its soldiers as getting pigs, and now these people have a higher incident rate of cancer, genetic problems.
What's your response to those charges?
It's a bunch of baloney.
For my money, it's complete baloney.
They didn't get enough exposure out of their participation in Nevada.
to change anything that was going to happen to them as far as I'm concerned.
And most of their troubles, I think, are imaginary with a vision somewhere in their mind of Uncle Sam taking care of them from now on.
And I've got no truck with any of them.
I don't think there's anything to it at all.
And did the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project or when you were in charge of the AEC, did they carry out their own investigation of these charges?
Well, of course these charges didn't arise until very recently.

The AEC at the time, and the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project at the time, and the Army at the time for that matter, tabulated all of the exposures, and all these people had film badges, and they were turned in, and everything was tracked as well as it could be tracked at that time.
And whether there were any individual overexposures, overexposures being something beyond what the limits had been set for the exercise, I don't know.
I didn't hear any.
But if so, there were damn few.
And they weren't the people that Mike Wallace was talking to.
Now, during the 1950s,
there were a couple hundred above ground explosions?
Is that about an approximate number, about two hundred were there?
That may be a little high, perhaps a hundred fifty, something like that.
I could count them, but it would take a while.
Okay, now today of course we have a strong environmentalist lobby, and we don't have above ground testing anymore.
The question is,
Some people have said, why did the government have to carry out so many tests?
What would your response be?
There are about three reasons, I think.
First, I think that knowledgeable people, in terms of our security, would agree that it was in our best interest to get on with the development of nuclear weapons
and getting them into the stockpile in usable form.
If one did agree to this, starting from where we were, with one test and two detonations on the enemy, that's not much background.
No, not much knowledge.
And so we had to move.
We had a long, long ways to go.
Those first devices, I'd hate to hesitate to call them weapons, were very heavy, clumsy devices.
We couldn't have built a national defense
based on that kind of a piece of mechanism.
So we not only had to develop the physics and nucleonics of nuclear weapons, we had to develop the hardware and the deliverability and the safety and all these various things.
Now, they say, could you have tested them below ground?
Well, in retrospect, yes, we could have, except we didn't know enough about it at that point to know whether we could or not.
That is a research project that takes a little time also.
So while we were testing below ground, we were also testing below ground and developing the techniques for testing below ground.
How one instruments
at a thousand or two thousand feet below the surface is a pretty rough problem by itself.
It probably costs something like one-tenth as much to test above ground as it does below ground.
Some effects would have to be determined above ground.
They just could not be determined below ground.
As an example, what effect does a high-altitude explosion have on the ionosphere?
You'll never find out the answer to that testing 2,000, 3,000 feet below the surface.
So some things had to be done in the air.
I think those were all adequate reasons for the things that we did.
We took quite extreme precautions in terms of safety from fallout and contamination.
It's true that there were some times when the weather didn't act just exactly as we had projected.
was a little fallout dropped off-site.
But in nearly all cases, that's been blown up by the press, and the actual damage from it is either negligible or not at all.
Now, as far as the development of the bomb itself, have
To my knowledge, we have never dropped two atomic bombs close by simultaneously.
Is that true?
Never detonated two of them close together?
Within a mile or two apart from each other.
Well, I hadn't thought about it.
Let me see.
Because this is important, of course, for the MIRV and the multi-warheads that we have today.
If we could think just hypothetically, what would happen if two or three or four bombs hit a city in one area just a few miles apart?
Do we know?
We certainly could calculate.
I think the answer is yes, we know.
We don't know from experience.
There's a difference.
But it would not be difficult to calculate.
All one would need is the conditions under which the four detonations went off.
I mean, by that location, altitude, and size of the individual detonation.
The rest of it could be calculated pretty easily.
And I'm sure it has been.
I haven't done it, but I'm sure it has been.
But as far as you know, we've never done a multiple explosion.
No, as a practical matter, we haven't.
I don't know of anything in particular to be gained by it.
There's no mystery about it as far as I know.

Okay, well what about the idea that if you have one explosion with a shockwave moving out and then a couple miles away you have another one, what's going to happen when those shockwaves hit, or three or four of those hit at the same time?
I mean, I'm a novice, but that to me is somewhat of a mystery, and I was wondering— Well, it's not a mystery.
It will create a different kind of devastation along this area where the shock waves meet.
some more severe, some less severe, depending upon the conditions.
But again, that can be plotted and calculated, and it's not mysterious.
Okay, okay.
Now away from fiction and toward fact, and that is the test-ban treaty.
which was a fact, and signed between Kennedy and Khrushchev in 1963, which meant that the United States now would go underground with testing.
Were you for or against that?
Well, the treaty that was signed
I was against.
I have to qualify that.
I felt that we should have had a better treaty before we committed ourselves that far.
If one takes the position, well that's the best treaty you can get, which I think the President did take that position, or recognized that as a condition.
Then yes, I would have gone ahead and signed it, because there was just too much testing and there were going to be more, and we were getting into a bad situation.
This could slow down development in countries who had not devoted as much effort as we had to underground testing.
I think by that time we were fairly sophisticated in what we could do underground.
And we had done enough in the atmosphere that we knew the parameters, at least, of the effects that we would get in the atmosphere.
So there were nothing, no areas that, about which we knew nothing.
There were areas in which we would have liked to have known some more.
we had at least some knowledge about them and could go underground and go ahead with the development.
My reason for being against the treaty was the same as it is now.
If we have to give away our birthright in order to get those guys to agree to sign a treaty with us, then no treaty as far as I'm concerned.
What do you mean by that, give away our birthright?
Well, give them all the advantages and we kind of unilaterally go ahead and make ourselves nude.
I don't buy that in weapons testing or armament or any other area.
And if you have no way of verifying, they have no way of inspection, you can't believe the information that you do get,
uh, then I think you're just kind of standing around naked and waiting for, to get clobbered.
And I don't buy that.
I recognize that sometimes they have to go further than they want to in that direction.
And I think the President did that in the case of our test ban.
Whether it was a justified thing, I'm sure will take, uh,
a lot more years than I'm going to live to determine.
Did you express your views to President Kennedy on this?
Well, to the extent that anyone could, because you have, of course, regular mechanisms for that.
And my position there, I was on several working groups, and I had my people on several working groups that worked
daily with the ACDA and others in developing U.S. positions and putting our input.
And I've pointed all these things out.
And many times when you're in government, in our government, in these countries, you're not asked for a recommendation.
You're asked for evaluations and factual analyses.
And this is proper.
I mean, there's nothing wrong with that.
But that was mainly the area where I was and where my people was in that particular problem.
And we did that to the very best of our ability, and I think it was good because we had some very capable people.
Okay.
Now, when the test ban treaty was
You were with the Atomic Energy Commission.
Yes, I was their manager.
What impact did it have on the AEC, and did you have any friends back at the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project that could tell you what impact it had on them?
Well, yes, we worked with them constantly, and the impact on them would have been the same as it was on us, as a matter of fact.
It had the effect of slowing down our development program and making it much more costly.
I guess there were some lesser effects, but those are the two main things that it did.
Another thing I was interested in was
those early tests, like Bikini and some of the other ones, do you remember what your first impressions were when you saw your first nuclear explosion or atomic explosion?
Yes.
I was on one of our communications ships—I've forgotten the name of it now—in Bikini
or just out of Bikini Lagoon.
When the shot was fired, it was one drop from an airplane and one off at two thousand feet about.
Maybe not quite that high, I've forgotten exactly, but it was an air burst anyway.
And it was my first view of a chain reaction of a nuclear detonation, a nuclear explosion.

and the suddenness and the magnitudes and the disruption that was caused by it, all within milliseconds, was something that's a little difficult for your mind to follow unless you've had some practice, and I had no practice at that point.

And of course, in the South Pacific, with the very, very moist air, with the shock wave ballooning out from the explosion, and it formed a dense cloud in the form of a diving bell with the bottom on the surface of the water that gradually expanded and went out.
this huge explosion with all of its colors and boiling and disruption was suddenly closed in this diving bell of clouds.
And almost equally quickly, that was dispersed by the heat.
And so it was a very spectacular show.
if you were thinking in terms of being on target and comparing that with being on target against other weapons that we had just finished a war using.
made your mind stop working for a little bit to do some thinking, because you could not see how anything could survive.
And even under a bomb barrage in World War II, you could visualize that if you were under the right covert or someplace, there was a chance you could get by.
But your mind told you that there was no chance there.
Actually, that doesn't turn out to be correct, but almost.
So it was, well, it's a highly emotional scene, the first one you see.
You think of the forces of nature that you didn't know about, and how great they are, or what great magnitude they are.
It shakes you a bit.
Did you change over time when you saw more and more of these?
No, I didn't.
It grew.
Because that explosion I think was around twenty megatons as I remember, more or less that anyhow.
I mean twenty kilotons.
I went on to see explosions of many megatons under various circumstances.
And that first flash is always the same.
It's just bigger and more telling on your mind.
There were British advisors at that test, weren't there?
There were.
British, not advisors, but witnesses at that test?
Yes, there were.
French, too?
Yes, there were, well there were several, many foreign countries there.
Were the Russians invited?
Yes, Russian was right on board my ship.
He was standing on deck with me when we watched it go up.
What was his comment?
Not so big.
Not so big?
That's what he said?
That's all he said.
Not so big.
Not so big.
Some people have contended that we invited the Russians to this to make sure that
They saw what would happen to them if they didn't come to some post-war agreements with us.
I can't answer that.
I don't know why they were invited.
Of course, the Russians were not the only ones.
There were a lot of others.
So I can't answer that.
I was in the Joint Staff and relatively new at it at that time, so I don't know what the rationale was.
Okay.
I'd like to know about selling atomic energy.
During the 1950s, the government

carried out a campaign, basically, and a lot of companies did, an attempt to convince the American public that atomic energy was not only safe, but it might resolve a number of the questions like power and energy.
And I was wondering if
at the Special Weapons Project or at the AEC, if you were in any way involved with some of those campaigns?
Yes, not at the Special Weapons Project, because we were concerned solely with weapons and power reactors for military purposes.
But in AEC,
And as general manager, well, yes, I was deeply involved in all of those campaigns.
Not so much in trying to sell someone something.
Our job, the whole purpose of creating the Atomic Energy Commission was to provide a means of developing atomic energy from its early status there.
to peaceful applications for MADCON.
All of us firmly believed that it had the capacity for that application and for achieving that goal.
And we spent a lot of taxpayers' dollars to get there.
And what we really were doing was defending our actions
in developing the nuclear energy for peaceful purposes.
And we're not consciously on a campaign to sell it, except to convince people, particularly Congress, that we were on the right track in development in the best interest of the United States.
And in spite of the fact that nuclear energy has taken a tremendous back step, I still think that we were right at that time.
And if we had continued to have support as we did, well, during the time that I was there and before that, half of the
Power in the United States would not be coming from nuclear energy, and it would be half the price it is right now.
And many, many other applications, too.
The fact that people's hands have been tied in the development of the peaceful applications of
nuclear energy, particularly in power, to me is a crime against the United States that is unforgivable.
It demonstrates to me a gullibility of some of our people that makes me sick.
Well, what about the argument
course that many opponents of nuclear energy say in contemporary America, and that is that they point to Three Mile Island.
They point to Three Mile Island and the accident we had there a couple of years ago.
What's bad about Three Mile Island?
I'm just asking you.
Well, I'm telling you.
I mean, I'm saying that this would be the question, I think, to somebody who points to Three Mile Island.
you tell me what happened at Three Mile Island that was bad.
So far as I can find, not a damn thing.

The only thing that was bad about Three Mile Island is that some people got out among the populace who lived close by, whipped them up to a fever pitch, and got them going all about nothing, and caused a hell of a big problem.
